BE

Citi can summarise.

BE

DMGT's results follow what is becoming a relatively familiar pattern with an overall relatively robust performance in B2B undermined by continued weakness on the consumer side of the business, and in particular print advertising where trends remain stubbornly negative into the 3Q despite the easing comp profile. The upshot of this is a downgrade to guidance and with it likely downward pressure on consensus EPS. While on one level we would argue this is partially discounted in current valuation (13x 2016E P/E, nearly 10% FCF yield) it is nevertheless a disappointment and will likely be taken poorly.

BE

Results vs. Expectations

DMGT has delivered £950m of revenue in the 1H, up c. 3% on a reported basis but down 1% on an underlying basis. This compares against our expectation of 1H revenue of c.£939m and 1% underlying growth. Group adj. operating profit for the period came in at £138m (14.5% margin) below our estimate of £142.6m (15.2%). However, adj. diluted EPS of 27.9p was 1.5% ahead of our 27.5p estimate reflecting lower financing costs and tax. Interim DPS of 6.7p (13% payout on reported EPS) was slightly behind our estimate of 6.9p.

11:18 am
BE

Focus #1: Divisional Organic Trends Overall Slightly Weak But Consumer Worse Than B2B

The 1H trends can be characterized as a game of two halves. Although still a miss vs expectations, overall B2B organic growth is relatively robust at +1% with the individual components not a million miles from expectations (RMS +1% vs Citi +2%; DMGi +6% vs +8%; Events +5% vs +7%; Euromoney -6%, already reported). On the consumer side of the business, however, the miss was more pronounced (-3% vs Citi -1%) with particularly acute pressure on print advertising (down -13% in the 1H and -15% in the 2Q). Digital did grow (+23%) but not enough to mitigate the print decline, leaving overall advertising -4% in the 1H.

BE

Focus #2: Outlook Downgraded at Consumer; Unchanged for B2B

For each of the B2B divisions the broad guidance is unchanged: RMS - low single digit u/l rev growth and c. 14% margin; DMGi - c. 10% u/l rev growth and mid-teens margins; Events - mid-single-digit u/l rev growth and 25% margins; ERM - 2H 'similar' to 2H last year and FY outlook 'in line with mgmt expectations'. Again the focus is on the consumer piece where, given the tougher top line (no improvement in trend into May despite easing comps), expectations on margins have been trimmed to 'around 10%' from the previous expectation of c. 13%.

Here's Morgan Stanley to take us through the numbers.

BE

- Pets at Home issued a Q4 trading update a few weeks ago, so today's profit
figures were always likely to be broadly in line with consensus expectations. So
they have proved to be: Pre Tax Profits for FY 2015/16 have come in at £95.3m
(versus a Bloomberg consensus of £95.1m)
- Although there is a strategy update here from the new CEO, there doesn’t
appear to be any significant changes in approach worth highlighting (which is
perhaps not surprising given that he had been CFO, and an integral member of
the management team, for several years)

11:30 am
BE

- Current trading is in line with management's expectations and the guidance
for the year ahead (which is 'new news') all looks to be broadly in line with
consensus forecasts
- Probably the most significant development here is a big (39%) increase in the
dividend, with the company changing its dividend policy to target a 50%
payout ratio
- Having spoken with the company this morning, we are not anticipating much
change to consensus forecasts for FY 2016/17 today. According to Bloomberg,
consensus is currently looking for Pre Tax Profits of £99m this year (equating
to 15.1p of EPS)
- Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts, Pets at
Home is trading on 16.1x Calendar 2016 earnings, 10.5x EBITDA with a 2.5%
dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 14.8x,
8.6x and 3.1% respectively

BE

FY16 estimates are slightly ahead of estimates and the group is moving to a higher dividend payout ratio.
PETS is a stable, growing and cash generative business occupying a defensible market niche. We believe the shares are worthy of a sector premium and hence retain our Buy rating and 300p target price.

BE

FY PBT slightly ahead: FY PBT of £97.3m (53 weeks)/£95.3m (52 weeks) is
1.7% ahead of our estimates. PETS issued a Q4 pre-close statement so there
are no revenue surprises.
Paying out more cash: The group has declared that it is moving to a 50%
payout ratio (vs. c.40% in FY15) and as a consequence is paying a FY
dividend of 7.5p (+39%). Going forward the group intends to maintain leverage
of c.1.5x net debt/EBITDA (vs. 1.3x as at FY16). Cash flow priorities going
forward will include ongoing organic investment in the business, ordinary
dividends, investment in adjacent business lines (e.g. vet referral centres) and
finally special dividends.
FY17 guidance – slightly higher capex: Adding 15-20 superstores, 45-55
vets, 50-60 groom rooms, NLW impact maintained. Capex of £45m includes
£5m on a £8m two-year energy saving project.
We are not expecting significant change to consensus forecasts today
(£98.7m, 15.6m), valuing the stock on a c.7% sector P/E premium.

11:43 am
BE

Who can we quote here? Canaccord?

BE

Another solid year from sales growth of 24% to just over £2bn, with CG adjusted PBT (ie
adding back pre-opening costs which B&M treats as exceptional) up 18.6% to £153.8m.
CG adjusted EBITDA was up 15.3%, so there has been some operational deleverage
relative to the strong top line growth. The PBT outturn was therefore below our forecast
of £157m, held back by some operational disruption associated with the opening
and integration of two additional warehouses.These are now reported to be operating
normally.
The full year dividend came in at 4.8p, an increase of 41.2%. In a welcome addition,
and in line with the company's capital structure policy, B&M has announced a special
10p dividend (£100m) to be paid on 5 August. Year end net debt reduced by £27m to
£354m.
UK LFL sales were up 0.3% for the year, and 2.4% on an adjusted basis. There are
two adjustments, namely delaying store entry into the LFL population until Month 14,
worth 0.6%; and excluding stores within a three mile radius of a new B&M store opening
for the first 12 months following the new store opening, worth 1.5%, and effectively a
cannibalisation measure.
Group gross margin fell slightly by 6bps to 34.5%, with the UK down 12bps. Next year,
new openings will revert to 50 net following 74 net new (vs 80 target) in the UK, which
ended the year with 499 stores. B&M has also announced the conditional agreement for
the acquisition of a small 9 store chain in Germany to bolster its international operations.
The German Jawoll chain will therefore see 19 stores added in FY17.
The company has had a "solid" start to the new year, but describes the "general
economic outlook" as "uncertain", which should theoretically be a positive for Value
players such as B&M.

BE

Impact on our view
We remain fans of the B&M roll-out story and its trading proposition. The eroding LFL
trend is optically unhelpful, but largely irrelevant to what is very much a space-driven
growth story. The warehouse integration issues appear to be over, so there should be
some reversal of the adverse impact on FY16's operating cost ratios in FY17, which
drove some of the operational deleverage. All this said, we believe the current valuation
reflects the earnings potential, hence our HOLD recommendation.
Valuation
The shares trade on a cal 16 PER of 20.4x, falling to 17.2x for cal 17, with corresponding
EV/EBITDA valuation metrics of 13.8x and 11.7x. These premium valuations reflect
the above average earnings growth relative to the wider sector from the store roll-out
programme, primarily in the UK and potentially also in Germany.

11:45 am
BE

An optically unhelpful eroding LFL trend is largely irrelevant to the space-driven
growth story.

BE

David Jeary, the analyst there, certainly has a way with words.

BE

Numis too, since they floated the thing.

11:46 am
BE

UK remains on track: A solid Q4, albeit with some LFL benefit from the early Easter,
enabled the UK division to post reported LFL of +0.3% for the FY, or +2.4% adjusted for
new store deflection and 'halo' effects. The space contribution of 24.4% reflected a net
74 openings to reach 499 at the YE, including acquisitions from certain major chains'
divestments and a more active developer pipeline. The gross margin eased -10bp,
with mix gains nearly offsetting a modest dollar sourcing headwind, while cost ratios
edged 60bp higher due to the addition of significant new DC capacity. EBITDA growth
of 16% was in line with forecasts. We believe that B&M's pricing integrity continues to
be reinforced and that conditions in the property market remain favourable, with the
UK chain's reach likely to comfortably exceed the current 850 target over time.
● A developing story in Germany: Sales growth of 18% at CER benefited from an
extra month and solid LFL progress. EBITDA growth of 22% at CER was boosted by
sourcing gains from the B&M network, assortment improvements and enhancements to
the store format. FY17 could be an interesting year as the new store formats are rolled
out and the group absorbs a bolt on deal. This should be underlined by an investor/
analyst visit on 17th June.
● FY17/18 EBITDA forecasts unchanged: We continue to expect further strong UK
profit growth in FY17 as the FY16 new store cohort contributes fully and a further 50
new stores are added. The LFL performance is likely to remain muted, at least during
H1 due to the lack of Easter and cannibalisation effect, before picking up in H2. We
forecast broadly stable EBITDA margins. We allow for a slightly higher depreciation
rate (1.1% of sales vs 0.9%) and the interest effect of the special dividend, but leave
our EPS estimates unchanged due to a lower tax assumption.

11:52 am
BE

Underlying performance indicated to be broadly in line with
expectations: Imagination is indicating that the underlying performance,
before one-off items, has been broadly in line with expectations provided in
previous update in Mar '16. Royalty revenue was slightly ahead while
licensing revenue was lower than expectations. Company is indicating that
underlying opex was in line with expectations. Net debt at the end of FY16
improved modestly to £33m from £35.4m at the end of FY1H16 and is
better than JPMe/company consensus of £34.4m/37.5m.

BE

One-off items to substantially impact reported items: The company
expects the reported revenue and adj EBIT to be materially below market
expectations as a result of some legacy system-on-chip (SoC) design
services revenue contract adjustments (company has refocused it SoC design
activities and is exiting/renegotiating low-margin/loss-making contracts) and
bad debt write-offs on two specific customers. Further, the company will
classify an additional £2.2m of revenue as discontinued operations as part of
the ongoing restructuring program. Total one-off restructuring charges,
associated with the previously announced £27.5m gross cost reduction
program, are likely to exceed £50m though cash restructuring charges are
expected to be much lower at less than £7m.

BE

Progress on restructuring indicated: The company is indicating progress
on the previously announced £27.5m cost cutting plan with the targeted Pure
sale indicated to be attracting considerable interest from potential buyers.
Imagination expects to sell Pure by end of 2016. The company is confirming
that benefits from £27.5m restructuring program will be delivered in full in
FY17. The company intends to announce the initial results of its ongoing
operational review with FY16 results on 5 July.

11:53 am
BE

ommentary on FY17: Company is indicating strong demand for licenses
for its core technologies. It is expecting revenue growth in FY17 with some
of this growth coming from already contracted and re-negotiated SoC design
services contracts. Company consensus is looking for FY17 revenue of
£135.2m with 2.5% growth. Though given the lower revenue base from one-
off impact on revenue in FY16, it is not clear if the current FY17 consensus
revenue will be achieved.

BE

Perhaps someone will buy Imagination, eventually .....

BE

.... But with half its revenue coming from one company, that's boxed in at the moment due to Takeover Panel rules, and with that customer likely to exit if anyone else buys it, the game theory involved is far from simple.

11:55 am
undefined
PM

We havent mentioned oil over $50

PM

Which it is

11:55 am
PM

Here's are a few quick points from Julian Jessop

PM

chief economist at Cap Economics

PM

The recovery in oil prices should be a net positive for the global economy but is not without its
downsides, including the support it might provide to the hawks at the Fed.

11:56 am
PM

First, the rebound in oil prices is consistent with the relatively positive views we have already been
outlining in our dedicated Commodities and Energy services. (See, for example, our quarterly
Commodities Analyst, “Oil to lead a broad-based recovery”, published on 1st February.) Indeed, we
expect further gains – to around $60 – for both Brent and WTI in 2017.
 Second, the recovery is, on balance, good news for the global economy and for equity prices. (See
Chart 1.) Prices in the $50 to $60 range would be high enough to ease some of the pressure on
producers, while still low enough to boost spending on other goods and services (at least relative to the
$100 plus that some thought was the “new normal” a few years ago).

PM

Third, though, higher oil prices are clearly better news for producers, or mixed producers/consumers
such as the US, than they are for consumers. In particular, the rebound in oil prices will sap some of the
momentum from the economic recoveries in the euro-zone and Japan. We are also wary of interpreting
the recovery in oil prices itself as a sign of a pick-up in global activity, as it mainly reflects disruption
on the supply side. (See our Energy service for more.)
 Fourth, the path from here is likely to bumpy. Indeed, as Chart 2 shows, oil prices staged a similar
recovery in the early months of 2015, only to fall sharply. The slump in 2014 also took place in the
second half of the year. There is a high chance of at least a temporary correction over the remainder
of this year too, as some of the supply disruptions ease or as US drilling activity rebounds in response
to higher prices. (See Chart 3.) These risks are reflected in our end-2016 forecasts of $45.

PM

Finally, the rebound in prices removes another reason for the Fed to delay raising US interest rates.
Admittedly, inflation expectations are still well anchored around 2% despite the jump in oil prices
(see Chart 4), but it is increasingly hard to argue that deflation is a serious threat to the US economy.
